comments.text:
In all fairness, marijuana is not entirely harmless. Several studies have 
found that prolonged use of marijuana produces a distinct cluster that 
appear with a fairly degree of reliability upon stopping use of marijuana. 
These symptoms are mainly psychological, with some studies finding some 
degree of physical (increased sweating and heart rate) symptoms as well. 
These are not severe symptoms, and they only occur with intense daily use. 
But it's not a drug that one should be arrested for using or EVEN selling.﻿

comments.text:
Yes - this is why conservatives hate government!

I am a strong fiscal conservative (more of a libertarian) and oppose the 
welfare state & minimum wage law (I think we should replace all that with 
the negative income tax)...  I oppose federally run schools (we should 
transition it with vouchers & school choice).  I tend to find TYT overly 
emotional and often very one-sided on a lot of issues, and they tend to 
demonize Republican stances by cherry picking extremists (like religious 
nutts) or twisting things like "oh you don't want men to be treated like 
garbage, you must be anti-women" etc.

However, I am 100% on-board with legalizing marijuana.  I wouldn't use it, 
but it's relatively harmless.  Treat marijuana problems as a public health 
issue (and maybe a potential social ill) - not as a criminal issue.  The 
police state & the prison industrial complex does not solve all problems!

TYT stop being so anti-Republic.  Let's get together based on specific 
issues (not party lines) and fight the police state.  We need good law 
enforcement who is accountable for their actions.  We need humane prison 
systems that focus on rehabilitation and protecting us from people who are 
actually dangerous.  And we need to end the war on drugs - starting with 
the complete legalization of marijuana.

Finally let me add that the "bust black kids" garbage is leftist 
propaganda. Yes it's true that there may exist racism and injustice against 
blacks in the criminal justice system... But let's also not deny the simple 
fact that blacks do commit more crimes. Not all blacks, and this says 
nothing about any individual person who happens to be "black" (in fact, I'd 
argue that most of our common conception of "race" is based more on culture 
than on biology). So TYT you can address the marijuana issue without 
spouting leftist propaganda and trying to turn everything into some kind of 
appeal to a demographic group like "oh we want to help blacks because they 
are oppressed". Guess what - non-"black" people (or people who are 
partially black) have their lives ruined by the drug war too! So don't sit 
over there and pretend like you have to be "black" to get your life ruined 
by the police state.

It breeds contempt for the law and disrespect for law enforcement - TYT you 
are absolutely right, and Miltion Friedman the great libertarian free 
market economist agrees. The way he put it was "inimical to the moral 
fabric of society". Milton Freedman gave the historical example of corn 
laws in Great Britan causing an adverse effect on culture that caused more 
crime and corruption. When the law is absurd, more people lose respect for 
the law, and more people stray from being adult respectable responsible 
upright honest hard-working individuals, and some will even enter a life of 
crime, and some they start a life of breaking only absurd laws but once 
they are in that lifestyle they will break other laws too. It also makes 
the USA government look bad to the USA public, and our credibility to other 
countries.﻿

comments.text:
Was listening with an open mind until the comment was made about weed not 
being harmful and about living under a rock. 

That is not a fact and therefor anything that comes after that is based on 
something that isn't true. 

Scientific evidence says the smoke from it is harmful, just as cigarette 
smoke has been proven to be harmful. That is a fact. 

Whether it should be illegal is a different matter. I'm not convinced it 
should be illegal. However, I can't listen to someone make a statement as 
fact that is not without losing respect for that persons creditability. 

People who want it to be legal need to stop arguing untrue items, in my 
opinion. 

The fact is that no one has got a right to tell anyone that they can't use 
this or that item. 

Legalize it all and let communities and parents teach their kids to make 
the right choices. 

Those that don't will pay a consequence. ﻿

comments.text:
+cindybin2001   Yes, I know several psychologists that would read these 
posts, if asked, and render a professional opinion.  It's really not that 
hard to find a mental health counselor.  They have them at school 
districts, community colleges, and 4-year colleges, plus those who work 
independently.  For someone who describes herself as an older woman, you 
seem out of touch with regard to finding a mental health counselor.  Heck, 
if you called the mental health department of your city, they would be able 
to put you in touch with a counselor.  It's really not that hard.  But I 
can see that you are already trying to wiggle out of my proposition by 
making it sound like you don't know where to find a mental health counselor.

As for your other questions... I am 25 years old; my parents are at their 
home (where else would they be);  they don't know that I'm specifically 
"like this" with you, but they do know that I have enough intelligence to 
question assertions when I disagree with them (like your assertions);  I 
have smoked pot on a few occasions, but I didn't like the trip it took me 
on.  I prefer to be up, rather than down.  So, I like crystal meth a lot 
more because it makes me feel like I'm king of the world!  Plus, it's less 
expensive than cocaine.

And before you go on one of your rants about how drugs screw one up and 
they are illegal, I'll have you know that I graduated summa cum laude from 
one of the top 10 universities in the US and I have a MBA from one of the 
top 5 business schools in the US.  So, drugs obviously haven't screwed me 
up.  As far as them being illegal, I don't care.  I know the risks.  I am 
safe with my use so that I don't attract police attention.  And I'm 
responsible for my own actions.  I don't tell others what to do with their 
lives and, conversely, I don't allow people to tell me what to do with my 
life.

It is not for some meddling, doll-collecting, busy-body to tell me how to 
live my life.  I know the risks all the way around and am willing to accept 
them and, to date, my life has been spectacular.  So, stop trying to treat 
me and everyone else like you are their mother; you aren't.  My own mother 
doesn't meddle as much as you do.  You are just a sad, mentally-touched 
woman who has way too much time on her hands.  Get a grip.  Now I'm off to 
smoke a bowl.

That's All.

+HeartOfSky DCUO My point was that "dangerous" is less specific than 
"addictive".

So asking someone like Mr Boticelli in this video, who's clearly being 
evasive and trying to avoid giving a direct, clear answer, the question 
allows him to weasel out of it a little bit easier and beat around the bush.

Are meth/cocaine more addictive? Nobody could seriously answer anything 
other than "yes".
But more dangerous? Like I say, that's less well defined. *Of course we 
know meth is more dangerous*, but it would be easier to avoid giving a 
direct response to that question.
{For example, at some point methamphetamine must have been FDA approved (I 
assume, since it was prescribed) but as far as I know, marijuana has not 
(?)}.

As for 20 bongs vs 1 mg, I guess that's speculation, experience, common 
sense. Again, just making the point that marijuana *could* be considered 
more dangerous in some extreme circumstances, but it could never seriously 
be considered more addictive.

Meh...just sayin

comments.text:
+recalcitrist1 Obviously they mean on average... 365 day/yr * 24 hr/day * 
60 min/sec * 60 sec/min = 31536000 sec/yr. So 31536000 sec per yr / 657,000 
people arrested per yr = one person arrested every 48 sec. Or if 8.2 
million were arrested between 2001 and 2010, that would be 8,200,000 / 10 = 
820,000 per year. So over that 10 year period period it's actually an 
average of one person arrested every 38.46 sec for marijuana.

believe it or not, methamphetamine are both schedule II substances, meaning 
that while they have a high addiction potential they have medical uses. 
 Cocaine is actually a (rarely used) topical anesthetic and methamphetamine 
is used in the treatment of extreme cases of ADHD (much like ritalin it's 
stimulant nature helps the mind focus more effectively (when taken 
appropriately)).  Opium, furthermore, is still schedule II (cough 
suppressant, opiates make excellent cough suppressants, codeine/guaifenesin 
syrup being a particularly popular formulation); fentanyl, an opiate pain 
killer with a potency roughly 100 times that of morphine (schedule II) and 
25 times that of heroin (schedule I).  Now this begs an interesting 
question: why is fentanyl, a far more powerful drug than heroin, schedule 
II compared to schedule I?  Now the argument could be made that heroin is 
produced and used in less than clinical settings, while fentanyl is made 
and administered typically in a clinical sitting.  And while it is true it 
is not really an effevctive argument since fentanyl is very often used 
illicitly (it is one of the most popularly diverted drugs by medical 
professionals, for example)  and given adequate chemical know-how could be 
produced in non pharmaceutical settings. Furthermore, meth is a schedule 
II, and anyone curious what backyard meth production and use looks like can 
see hundreds of videos here on youtube giving a fairly good idea of that. 
 The overwhelming majority of meth users in America were not prescribed it, 
suffice to say.  So why does cannabis (an anxiolytic and appetite 
stimulant) and heroin (an effective pain killer, cough suppressant, and 
antidiarrheal) remain schedule I.  Stigma.  That is it, and that is the 
reasoning behind the scheule I classification.  Meth'd probably be on there 
too if it hadn't been scheduled prior to the meth boom.  Drug 
classification is heavily heavily stigmatized.  Pure, simple, illogical.﻿

With that out of the way let's take a step back on this argument so we can 
understand some of the principles that are at play and have a logical 
framework for which we can base our ratiocination (the flow of Logic) on. 
If drug use and possession is illegal only one force (in worldly systems) 
has authority over that. That would be the State. Notice I didn't say 
Government but State (I am not talking about the fifty states versus 
Federal Government). I am making a distinction here Between state and 
government because these two are entirely different in their origin and 
effect. Government is by the people and for the people. State comes from 
the primitive past when a conquering tribe takes over another for economic 
control. This is a society of Hegemony (slavery) and is the enemy of every 
free man. (based on ideas in "The Law" by Frederic Bastiat) Government 
happens because People have a right to Life Liberty and property. Since 
they have that right they also have a right to protect their Life, Liberty, 
and Property. They can also work with others (as a social Body) to ensure 
that protection. This is where Government comes from. Men don't have these 
rights because of Laws existence but rather Law exists because men have 
these rights. In other words, our rights do not come at the whim of 
Government but from God. As such I believe that there are 3 legitimate and 
proper roles of a Government 

1. The equal Protection of Life, Liberty, and Property under the law. (this 
can include Police, firehouses, war, etc... it also includes the right of 
regulation on anything that falls under these 3. Hence a right to regulate 
safety standards).

2. The promotion and upkeep of Public lands.

3. The power to tax only to fulfill those first 2 roles.

(of course there is one qualifier that must be adhered to, that is equal 
rights to life Liberty and property. In other words, I and/or my rights 
cannot violate the rights of another. Hence the old adage "First, do no 
harm.")

In such a Government I cannot force my neighbor (through violence) to be 
learned, economical, and sober. I can only force them to be Just (that is 
to say, to not violate another man's Life, Liberty or Property). As such 
how can I delegate that right to force people to be learned economical and 
sober. I personally do not have that right I cannot delegate that right 
away to someone else nor can I delegate that right to the social body. By 
the very definition of delegation alone it is evident I have to possess 
that right prior. As such it is not government that takes force over 
someone else's vices. Only State can do that and what you are asking for is 
an evil far worse than someone's vice (you are wanting State). You are 
wanting people who think they have a right to take by force and control 
free men and yet be free of control themselves. Hence you want special 
rights to groups of people and in this case to the controlling class who 
are but mere men. In this you have a logical inconsistency. What you are 
saying is that Person A and Person B cannot own themselves but can be owned 
by or partially owned by persons C and/or D. Can't you see this is 
completely incompatible with a free people. Also, this is not Gods ruling 
if you remember he didn't want Israel to have a king over them because a 
man would be over them. He even goes as far as to say that Satan is the 
Prince of this World. This is not a mistake, it is a claim that Satan is 
the one ruling over the Kingdoms of this world (hence why he could offer 
them to Jesus if he only bowed down to him). What you want then is, Satan's 
system to perform (what you think) is God's will. This doesn't make any 
Logical sense. Let's use evil to accomplish good. No. If you doubt the evil 
of State look at the how State Steals, Kills, and destroys. Wasn't that the 
very definition of Satan by Jesus himself?

How can you possibly think using State to force people to be sober and free 
of vices is a right you possess. If you agree with State doing this then 
you have offered consent that you can indeed force with violence via the 
medium of state to stop people from having vices. You do not have that 
right. If you did then it would be perfectly legal and moral for you to 
shoot up a bar or lock a drug user in a cage in your basement. You can see 
in this you clearly do not have such a right. But I digress, I have yet to 
even enter into the problems I have with the drug war (which far outweigh 
those problems associated with the use of drugs). I will await your 
response before I even get into that part of this subject. I just wanted 
you to have a logical framework to think about this subject in.  

I will wait for your response and chat soon. Thanks :)

SEEN marijuana! I never even THOUGHT about pot before all this! 

AND I AM NOT A "PROHBITIONIST"! Oh you people make me so mad, always 
accusing me of that! The more you all focus on the law and call me a 
"prohibitionist", the more I say that pot should be illegal forever, with 
VERY STIFF PENALTIES. Again, it is not because of marijuana itself, but

But the more you guys keep bringing up the law and calling me a

right and doesn't mean YOU have to! Aren't you better than that? That is

pot smoker. At least the junkie has an excuse; they are addicted and 
hopefully will get help. But casual pot smokers, just like casual drinkers, 
have no excuse. They can't even see why it is wrong and immature to use 
mind-altering drugs recreationally. And that is why we have to talk some 
sense into them! 

And when did I say I don't know anything about pot? Maybe when I was being 
sarcastic after you guys CONTINUALLY accuse me of not knowing anything 
about pot, even though I have been saying for ten years online that I dare

true.

And it is DRUG when you use it to get high and stoned and have "Fun". That 
is what makes it wrong. And if you get busted, it won't help to tell the

And then you say you will PRAY for me?? OH MY GOSH. What is it with you 
mean, immature pot smokers and praying? If you guys are all so dang

never smoked pot!! 

So anyway, again, I totally agree with you about the drug war! It is a

So I hope you realize now that you should help me speak up and talk some

real life who smokes pot, approves of it or knows where to find it! It is 
ILLEGAL!

comments.text:
Should all drugs be decriminalized and regulated? Regulation would funnel 
all the money to the government instead of dealers, it would take virtually 
all power away from dealers and cartels, which in turn could decrease 
overall violence and crime rates. Regulation would ensure quality standards 
were met, instead of dealers/cartels cutting corners that may put potential 
users in greater, unnecessary health risks. It could even be set up such 
that funds from purchased hard drugs could be used to create rehabilitation 
centers for those very users, among many other possible avenues.

Shouldn't it be up to the individual for him or her to decide what they 
want to put into their body, once they are made fully aware of the 
consequences of doing so? Obviously everything should have an age limit 
imposed like alcohol, cigarettes, and marijuana, but once an adult has 
reached the legal age where they are able to make an informed decision on 
using these goods, what business is it of ours to tell him no?

The absolute end of this spectrum of thought would be selling suicide pills 
over the counter. After all, alcohol and cigarettes are essentially "long 
term" suicide pills.

I dunno, this isn't very structured, but to me it seems overall better to 
decriminalize these substances, as it has been shown multiple times that 
banning and criminalizing them is completely ineffective.﻿

comments.text:
I have said "Shit" once to you, and it wasn't even directed at you. 
Personally, I see nothing wrong with saying whatever I want to illustrate 
my point, and if you take offense, then that is your prerogative. You are 
more than welcomed to walk away if you don't like my message. But as far as 
I'm concerned, I have been nothing but cordial to you and your responses.

You don't want to consume, marijuana, that's totally fine, I have 
absolutely no issue with that, I'm glad you have hobbies and outlets that 
help you through the day. But who are you to tell me what I should do with 
my free time? How arrogant can you be to assume that my coping mechanisms 
aren't real coping mechanisms.

I agree that adults should know better; they should know that any adult is 
entitled to do whatever they want with their free time, so long as they do 
not cause harm to non-consenting parties, and I think marijuana falls well 
within that category. I'm even of the stance that more dangerous drugs 
should be decriminalized so long as the harm is not passed on to someone 
who doesn't consent to being subjected to that harm, but I know you'll have 
absolutely none of that.

comments.text:
I don't care how awful other people have been to you. For one, they aren't 
me, and for another, their character does nothing to support or hinder the 
overall discussion, all that matters is the arguments and what evidence can 
support either side. The internet is choc-full of trolls and assholes, its 
all about how well you can ignore them to get to the substance of the 
argument.

As far as I can tell, you are only against marijuana because it is a 
mind-altering product. And I have shown several products that also alter 
minds, and yet these products get a pass because they don't specifically 
make you lethargic or absent-minded. and most damning of all, these effects 
are *temporary*. There is absolutely no good reason why a human being can 
not enjoy this substance in the privacy of their own home for an evening. 
People have shitty lives, and marijuana can help them move past their own 
difficulties.

Above all else, I still have yet to hear a sound reason why a consenting, 
physically and mentally mature adult cannot enjoy any substance he or she 
wishes to consume, knowing full well the effects and repercussions of 
consuming said substance, especially when doing so will not cause any harm 
whatsoever to anyone else that does not consent.

Its that simple.

comments.text:
+cindybin2001 Immature teens are just that - immature. In other words, they 
are not a mature adult. I am in complete agreement that teenagers should 
also not smoke marijuana, because they are neither physically or mentally 
mature. I consider them children as well, simply because they are not an 
adult. I don't think I can be more clear on the stance that my argument is 
only concerning humans over the age of 21.

"My whole point is that a grown adult should know more than anybody to not 
smoke pot!"

You still have yet to demonstrate why adults should know better. You say 
its illegal and I say the legality of it needs to be challenged. When 
pressed for why you think it needs to stay illegal, I can come up with 
multiple other products that offer similar effects upon consumption that 
are all perfectly legal and you shoo them away saying that they are not 
nearly the same as the examples I offer, without giving any good reason why.

"A MATURE adult wouldn't even be THINKING about getting high on pot!"

Millions do, every day, some even do it for medicinal reasons. Are you 
saying that all these people are immature?

"But even if pot were legal, it DOESN'T MAKE IT RIGHT!"

You still have failed to demonstrate why. Its a product that makes you 
temporarily lethargic and absent-minded for a few hours at most, what could 
possibly be wrong with wanting to consume a product that has those 
properties?

"We are against it because it's a mind-altering drug!!!"

And yet you are not against cheeseburgers, tea, warm milk, prescription 
medications, video games, tobacco, because they are all just "different" 
mind-altering products, and you have yet to clearly establish what the 
difference is. This is hypocrisy in its purest form, I'm sorry but you have 
yet to demonstrate your case to me

comments.text:
+cindybin2001 I'm simply not convinced that any major religion, including 
the church of latter day saints, has demonstrated any good reason for me to 
believe their ideologies. I guess I'm glad you found something that makes 
you happy, but it does nothing for me. I personally see no good reason to 
think there is a higher being directly intervening in our daily lives.

There is no common sense in banning a substance that does not cause harm to 
anyone that has not made the informed choice to consume said product, and 
the effects of consuming said substance are temporary at worst, and 
positive at best, when it can be clinically shown to have positive results 
for people with pre-existing conditions.

We've gotten off track, you have defined mind-altering to be any substance 
that gets you high, stoned, buzzed, or relaxed. These 4 sub-descriptions 
are also pretty wishy-washy, and it leads to interesting parallels when we 
consider other products that have these qualities as well. Tea or warm milk 
can make me feel relaxed after a long day. A whole slew of products can 
give me a 'high' by raising my dopamine levels, so why are these products 
passable and marijuana is bad?

Even if I give you the entire definition as you put it, what is so wrong 
with using a product to becoming high or relaxed? If its my body and I want

whatsoever, and that is an entire can of worms of itself that I wish to not 
get into right now.

is critical to hammer out all the necessary details,  before we even cover 
objection #2.

comments.text:
I don't want everyone high all day either.  I want people to be sober at 
work, sober when operating vehicles and machinery -- but on your own 
personal time, do what you want.  I smoked weed for well over a decade 
nearly every single day, but I went to work sober, drove sober, or when I 
had other responsibilities like babysitting, I didn't smoke up.  I think 
it's so vastly important to educate people on how to use it responsibly.

I gave it up going on 8-years now.  I don't have a want or need for it in 
my life at this stage.  I have progress on the horizon that requires me to 
be sober and never have drugs detected in my system and I am perfectly 
alright with that.  Sure, I can drink on my own time, but I'm not a big 
drinker.  I drink beer but not often.

With the massive burden on the prison system in the US, I think they really 
need to go back and release everyone who was locked up for minor marijuana 
charges.  Lift some of that burden on the taxes to run prisons, tax 
marijuana sales and pay your fucking debts, you stupid fucking political 
douchebags.

If you want to lock someone up for year for driving high, fine..  but 
walking down the street?  You've got to be fucking nuts.  It's time the 
federal gov't gets a fucking clue on how to run a country, to make money 
and pay their bills.  Issue marijuana receipts on bond paper and if someone 
has marijuana without receipt, then you can fine them the tax.  Just define 
a usage period, like a half q is good for 2 weeks from the purchase date - 
then the receipt is no longer valid.  This way you can cut down some on 
illegal, non-taxed sales.  People that are growing weed illegally now can 
be permitted to grow and earn and that gets taxed as well.  Provide 
legitimate jobs while everyone makes money and people have their weed.

People will argue with me that it shouldn't be regulated, but where your 
country is bankrupt, don't argue. ;)﻿

comments.text:
They don't want kids to believe that drugs are bad. They want them to 
continue questioning it and trying them so that they can continue profiting 
by creating  crime where before there was none. They don't care about the 
future of America or its' children. These people are traitors and our 
founding fathers would have no less than hanging them for treason if they 
were still around today. It's not right, it's not American, and it's up to 
us to put an end to it and see to it that our youth are properly educated 
about the effects of drugs.

It's easier for a kid to buy weed than alcohol these days simply because 
it's so common. Eventually, if not already, it's going to become easier for 
them to buy heroin as well. We have to tell them that we're not going to 
support the enforcement of victimless "crimes" any longer and if they can't 
stop being greedy assholes we'll just reform the entire system, then they 
can become a bunch of heroin addicted hobos with maggots for legs.

I am absolutely against public intoxication and driving under the 
influence, or even going to work while on drugs, but this shit has gotten 
out of control and it has to stop. It's our natural right to do whatever we 
please to our own bodies so long as we're not harming others, but without 
proper education our youth are simply not capable of sound reasoning and 
decision making skills. Yes, we should have restrictions on all drugs and 
laws that protect others from being harmed by their users, even marijuana 
must have a legal age to purchase unless it is a medical necessity.

There are studies showing that early marijuana use can inhibit the 
functions of the brain, but that's pretty much the only negative effect 
that it can have. The other problems start when an inexperienced user 
consumes a strain of marijuana that is very potent and has a high 
concentration of THC, the compound in marijuana responsible for the high 
that users receive, although none of these effects are long term the user 
will have an overall terrible experience and the short-term psychosis and 
paranoia can cause them to behave irrationally. Marijuana is however 100% 
safe when grown, processed, and used properly.

To any first time users of marijuana you should not be looking for a strain 
that has the highest THC content you can possibly find or you're gonna have 
a bad time. Start low and work your way up to the higher percentages 
slowly. If you're unfortunate enough to only be able to get your hands on 
illegally grown marijuana you can get a general idea of the potency based 
off what they call it. Dirt, schwag, and reg/reggie/regular are the lowest 
potencies that you can get your hands on. I recommend just starting with 
regular since the cheaper ones are basically glorified sacks of shit and 
will likely give you bronchitis if you smoke them.

Always use a water bong if you're unsure of whether the marijuana has been 
properly grown and flushed of all chemicals so that your smoke is filtered 
by the water, and don't put anything other than water in the bong, 
especially anything that has a fat content as THC is fat soluble and it 
will only steal what you lit up for in the first place. Never ever drink 
the bong water under any circumstances as it is filled with all the 
impurities from your marijuana, and it tastes just absolutely terrible 
anyways. You mind as well just dump a tray of ashes in there with it too if 
you're gonna. It will probably actually make it taste better somehow.﻿

comments.text:
What's more likely to be the drug that someone may try; Marijuana or LSD?  
I agree that most people would say pot as it seems so much less harmful and 
in fact is on the front end and short term.  But what is the long term 
effect of someone that feels more free to use pot?  There isn't a simply 
answer to the addictive properties that lead addictive personalities to 
their most destructive form.  What is the path to harder recreational drugs 
and alcohol?  Do people who are addicted to drugs and alcohol need to have 
the most invasive addictive substance to start down the path toward a 
severe addiction?  Is it possible that making less invasive options open 
make it possible to move to more invasive and far more addictive and in 
some cases fatal results?  AA and NA will tell you that it only takes one 
serving to move an addictive person toward their brink.  What about the 
prospective addictive personality?  What does it take for them to start 
down a destructive path?  Perhaps making any level of addictive substances 
that blind us from reality in any dosage are not the best idea?  Maybe 
natural ways of finding calm and peace are more objectively and 
subjectively able to be both more effective and have a greater health 
benefit?  Meditation has conclusive evidence that it can have effects on 
the blood pressure, stress levels and chemistry of the individual for 
healthy positive effects.  Exercise (Couldn't many use that in their life 
instead of junk food cravings?) is of great benefit to relieve stress, 
build resistance to disease and promote a healthier physiology over all.  
It seems so futile to argue that something is good just because it's NOT AS 
BAD.  I think that bad is bad and that it's better to engage in things that 
are good for one's self and the people YOU love.﻿

comparisson!﻿

comments.text:
Hey Gramps,
First, smoking cannabis is not at all like smoking tobacco.  Tobacco 
contains nicotine which is extremely carcinogenic whereas cannabis smoke 
contains no additional carcinogenic compounds other than that found in all 
forms of smoke (all smoke has minor carcinogens.)  It's not "smoking" that 
causes cancer, it's "smoking tobacco" that causes cancer.  In fact, 
researchers using the same epidemiological protocol as for tobacco found a 
negative correlation between cancer and the use of cannabis; meaning it 
appeared to provide protection from cancer.
Second, most people today use vaporizers, which burns with higher heat and 
gets rid of the tar while keeping the psychoactive components contained in 
water vapor.  No need to gunk the lungs up, Grampa.

You completely missed the fact that tobacco has nicotine in it while 
cannabis does not.  You kind of missed the elephant in the room. 

"...the ash present contains free radicals which cause mutations in DNA 
which cause the cancers that you see in tobacco smokers." 

So it's not due to the nicotine being burned with sugar that then causes 
phenyl aldehyde to form, which is far more carcinogenic than nicotine 
alone?  You're telling me that 50+ years of research hasn't found nicotine 
to be the carcinogenic compound in tobacco and it's really caused by "ash" 
creating DNA mutations which then cause cancer?  Dude, you need to smoke a 
joint.  Clearly your brain cannot get any more screwed up.  All smoke has 
minor carcinogens and can increase the risk of cancer slightly (keep in 
mind we're talking about subtle, statistical variations) but this is not 
the same thing as the issue with smoking tobacco, which has a specific 
carcinogenic compound.

"If you have worries about marijuana usage , don't announce them in a way 
it's politically handy for people to use as argumentation FOR keeping the 
current laws."

I don't have any worries.  It terribly affected my short term memory, 
concentration and clarity of mind but I'm not worried about it.

These are the arguments I find convincing for the legalization of marijuana.

1. Marijuana is way less harmful than alcohol or tobacco.

2.  People are going to get high anyway regardless of the laws, so 
legalizing it and taxing it will preserve all the money being spent on the 
drug war as well as take away the drug dealer's revenue's and put them in 
the US treasury.

But those two reasons pale in comparison to the third reason which is by 
far the reason that I find most convincing....
 
3.  It's not the government's place to tell me what I can or cannot put in 
my own body (this of course goes way beyond marijuana).

Those three reasons alone make the legalization of marijuana a necessity, 
but we shouldn't have to lie about it or be like sleazy politician's who 
take any opportunity given to them to speak, simply to regurgitate their 
talking points.

comments.text:
Clever one-liners.  "somewhere between a headache pill and a latte" ... 
"Botticelli ... makes a nice penne" ...  as the congressman makes clear, 
people simply don't credit the government when it comes to these commercial 
revenue protection schemes masquerading as a "war on drugs."  

The big difference for me is simple: marijuana is not addictive and can be 
a pain medication; alcohol is addictive and it impairs judgement, reason 
and motor skills.

In my experience (as a an employer of race car mechanics and home 
construction tradespeople) I'm okay with a work showing up after a night 
smoking mary jane, but if they show up with a hint of booze on them, 
they're given a one time warning and the second time, they're paid to the 
end of the week and they're gone.  If a worker with technical skills is a 
little high, there's absolutely zero risk on the job site or in the work 
place and the quality and productivity of their work is measured separately 
from their blood chemistry.  If a worker shows up "with a little buzz" then 
they have a serious and severe problem that represents a very real risk to 
their co-workers and to their customers simply because we know from 
scientific testing that alcohol impacts motor skills and risk assessment 
judgement.  Do you want to be working next to someone with cancer who has 
taken some pain medication or do you want to be working beside a person who 
has alcohol in their blood and needs help to cure their addiction? 

They need to protect the pharmaceuticals industry and they (the government) 
need to drive revenue to the prison industry.  They (government) need to 
protect alcohol and tobacco industries revenues and they make it a broad 
daylight crime with no accountability.﻿

comments.text:
The higher rate of supply of cannabis makes cannabis more habitual. Most 
habits are formed through wants and needs. Lot of people have spent well 
over a decade demanding the law be changed to accomodate the 'habitual, 
modestly used, pesticide" cannabis. One of the bigger problems that a study 
in a lab can't explain to you is the difference in airborne potency.

Alcohol can be smelled on the breath of drinkers, and a can of beer popped 
in a lounge can be smelled around the house after a few hours. Cannabis 
buds being smoked permeate through the air upto 20-30yards  in minutes and 
that smell lingers.

Picture this for a second, you are in suburbia, living in a cul-de-sac. the 
two houses at the top of the street go right at the top and go to the dope 
store, then smoke it with the windows open. You only go to the shop on the 
left, you walk through their pollution and it makes you feel uncomfortable.

Option two, 2 gardens are next to each other separated by a fence. There is 
a trampoliine in one, and a barbecue in the other.A kid in high school is 
bouncing up and down on the trampoline, with homework still to do. At the 
barbecue 40 revellers are blazing upwards of an ounce of dope thanks to 
their 'personal limit'. Kid gets passive inhalation and messes up his 
homework. You paying him? or allowing neighborhood pricing policy to 
rapidly shift the cost of your house depending on the habits of your 
neighbors?

Don't want to pay the tax on a $300k house? everyone blazes up and lowers 
the attractiveness of the area, then quit one year before everyone sells.

What's up with that?﻿

comments.author: Nun Ya

comments.text:
+Kara Bismarck Putting people in prison for drug possession alone is always 
a joke, but probably for marijuana more than any other drug (though you 
could make a similar argument for many psychedelics which have fewer 
established adverse effects and a lower potential for addiction).

Most research shows the addictive potential of THC to be lower than for 
caffeine, though measuring it quantitatively can sometimes be difficult. In 
particular, genetics seems to play a greater specific role in addiction to 
caffeine than in addiction to THC. That is, a greater proportion of people 
would be likely to become addicted to marijuana if they smoked enough of it 
regularly, while a smaller proportion of people would be likely to become 
addicted to caffeine when consumed in more reasonable quantities. There is 
also the somewhat arbitrary notion of equivalent doses between such 
different drugs.

In any case, there is no evidence that smoking just a few joints a day is 
likely to get anybody addicted, while people drinking just a few cups of 
coffee per day of course can get addicted, again supporting the greater 
addictive potential of caffeine.

That does not however mean that cannabis is completely benign, just 
relatively less addictive than the other drugs you compared it to. So if 
your main concern with drug use is addiction, you should be more concerned 
with coffee than with marijuana. On the other hand, if your main concern is 
with, for instance, impairment while driving, marijuana is probably more 
dangerous.

comments.text:
+Nun Ya
Lots of problems with the post.

First is the genetic fallacy, associating the argument with the source. The 
evidence stands on its own merit. If somebody else presented the exact same 
studies, you should give that person the same credence. Yes, I have smoked 
plenty of weed, but that just doesn't matter here.

Second and third are two simple lies in a row. Claiming that 
procrastination is the only unwanted side-effect of marijuana is silly when 
you think about it. At the very least, you should realize it can make you 
hungry, which is not always a desirable outcome. There are in fact dozens 
of other examples of fairly straightforward adverse effects. And claiming 
that alcohol (ethanol specifically) is the "only" chemical that affects all 
organ systems is even more ignorant. What about glucose?

Fourth is the naturalistic fallacy. Yes, marijuana is a plant. So is 
hemlock. But I would not recommend consuming hemlock recreationally. On the 
other hand, LSD is semi-synthetic. Guess which of those two chemicals 
(cicutoxin and lysergic acid diethylamide) is more dangerous.

Fifth is impugning my name with suggestions that I have been "bought and 
paid for", despite now over a dozen posts to the contrary. Again, this 
shouldn't matter. It's simply an ill-concealed ad hominem attack.

Sixth is the attempt to use language to distance marijuana from "actual 
drugs," an apparently artificial category consisting of drugs you consider 
dangerous by some arbitrary criterion. Do you really want to argue that 
marijuana is safer than melatonin? Tryptophan? Carbon dioxide?

Seventh is the suggestion that legitimate uses for the drug negate any 
possible side effects. As if the world were black and white, and useful 
drugs could never harm anybody. As a diabetic, let me assure you that 
insulin is both necessary for life and can kill you from an overdose, and 
the difference between the two is not that great. I am not "demonizing" 
insulin by pointing out the risks. And I am certainly not "demonizing" 
marijuana by pointing out the common (though of course not universal) but 
mild side effects and dependency it can cause.

And eighth is the changing of goalposts between the POSSIBILITY of quitting 
without symptoms and the CERTAINTY of it. Not all people have any problem. 
But some do, and probably more than you would believe without seeing the 
placebo-controlled studies.

experience would "prove" that it didn't work, and for the other half it 
would "prove" that it did. The preponderance of the studies clearly show 
the same symptoms occuring in a large proportion of people who stopped 
smoking marijuana after frequent smoking. The idea that the people who are 
reporting adverse effects are all lying, being bribed by the government, or 
are somehow deluded is preposterous. All you are doing is demonstrating 
that you have no idea how scientific research works, how THC acts in the 
brain, and how to evaluate evidence critically.

comments.text:
+Nun Ya Of course I've smoked weed. But again, the fact that you don't 
report these symptoms doesn't mean they don't exist. I have talked to many 
people who report the opposite, who say they cannot sleep without smoking 
weed. Why should I trust you over them? Because you use capital letters?

I do not for a second believe you are licensed to practice medicine if you 
think all studies cost millions or that they are all corporate funded. 
Actual doctors spend years directly involved in the research process and 
understand how grants work.

One good (though slightly outdated) example of an analysis of cannabis 
withdrawal syndrome is here: 
http://journals.psychiatryonline.org/article.aspx?articleid=177137. It 
cites numerous studies, including a double-blind inpatient three-way 
crossover study from 1999. In this study, patients in two groups were 
alternately given pills containing THC and placebos. Neither the doctors 
nor the patients knew which group they were in, but during days when the 
patients were given placebos, they reliably reported anxiety, depression, 
irritability, decreased quantity and quality of sleep, and decreased food 
intake.

Cannabis withdrawal symptoms have even been imitated artificially by 
introduction to CB1-antagonists, which effectively have the opposite effect 
of THC (and so elicit symptoms similar to THC withdrawal). (
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3717344/)

These were not funded by corporations and their authors did not state any 
competing interests. The studies were all published in peer-reviewed 
journals. But you have decided they must somehow be biased because they 
don't reach the conclusion you expect. Who is really biased here?

THC and other cannabinoids bind to cannabinoid receptors in the brain and 
lead to receptor downregulation. It would be a great surprise if this 
downregulation did not result in some form of withdrawal. It is well 
accepted that this is at least partially responsible for cannabis 
tolerance, and the existence of tolerance is also suggestive of withdrawal. 
Surely you do not deny these facts.
comments.author: EebstertheGreat

+TheIzma1 Except Marijuana DOES have predictable withdrawal symptoms, even

symptoms affect 50% of people, there is no reason to expect them to affect 
you. That's why clinical trials are preferred to anecdotal evidence.

+joedanero You're right. I went with what I read in the first place in a 
reputable paper, not following up on what was discovered later on - because 
frankly, I don't care that much about the topic. My bad.

Despite my own mistake in the matter, I'm not really sure how it changes 
the discussion.

The legalisation apologists have been on a constant course of retreat in 
public discourse, with every bit of actual knowledge researchers gained.

First, they claimed that it was harmless.
Then it was discovered that smoking marihuana damages the lung.
Then they claimed that it was harmless ~compared to~ tobacco.
Then it was discovered that it has addictive attributes and reduces 
cognitive functions.
Then they claimed it was harmless ~compared to~ alcohol.
Then it was was discovered that it can cause, and deepen, psychotic 
disorders.
Then they claimed that it only affects a small group of people, who have a 
disposition towards these things.
Then it was discovered that it can cause heart failure.
Then they claimed it only affects people with pre-existing conditions...

I mean, how long is this game of salami tactics supposed to go on, until 
the apologists realise that marihuana isn't what they want it to be ?

comments.author: writerconsidered

comments.text:
+joedanero
"The verifiable fact Ixider made is that alcohol is more dangerous than 
marijuana.  That's not a subjective belief."

This is simply false, as are the rest of your conclusions based on this 
false premise.

Alcohol, like any foreign substance (including cannabis -- and food, for 
that matter), is dangerous if you over consume.

At moderate levels, as I've already explained, many alcohols (particularly 
red wine, gin and whiskey) have positive health effects.

Cannabis, on the other hand, does not. While cannabis use (or, more 
accurately -- THC, which can be prescribed without cannabis use and the 
negative side effect of inhaling carcinogens), only acts to relieve the 
symptoms of existing illnesses.

And I don't support any government intervention in any substance. People 
should responsible for their own health. Part of that responsibility, 
however, involves providing people with accurate, honest information -- not 
simply promoting whatever biased findings support your position.
comments.author: AntitheistPOV

comments.text:
That is complete bullshit, you're going to explain? I'm sorry, but I 
generally prefer to get my explanations from someone who isn't full of 
shit. If anything the data is skewed in the other direction. No one is 
suggesting that Cannabis is completely harmless, it isn't. But it's vastly 
less harmful than alcohol, a substance that's been killing people, and 
ruining lives for most of recorded history. Mr O'Reilly who you probably 
really admire was putting forth a similar argument the other night.  He 
said that cannabis related driving deaths were up 30% in the last decade. 
What he failed to mention was the fact that they get these numbers because 
anytime someone involved in a fatal accident has cannabis in their system 
it is considered to be the cause. Bill failed to mention the other 
substances that were also involved, that wouldn't suit his purpose. He also 
failed to bring up the fact that  unlike most other intoxicants, cannabis 
is detectable in your system for up to 4 weeks after being consumed. I 
could have smoked cannabis last month, and nothing since, and if you tested 
me today I would still have cannabis in my system. I'm not saying that no 
one has ever got all buzzed and crashed their car, that would be an 
unreasonable assertion. But so is saying that driving fatalities are  up 
30% in a 10yr period all due to cannabis . I think the  last numbers for 
alcohol related deaths in the US for a year were in the 25.000 people 
range. This from a substance that's not only legal, but advertised to the 
hilt.  And don't even get me started on tobacco, the numbers are 
staggering. What has you people so frightened about cannabis legalization? 
Really, if you do some honest research, and don't get all your information 
from Fox News, and outdated government propaganda. You'll realize cannabis 
is a reasonably benign substance. I'm not saying it's completely harmless, 
few things are. But in comparison to alcohol, tobacco, and the vast 
majority of prescription drugs it doesn't even come close. It is time to 
end this  inane, unneeded, horribly expensive war on cannabis. If you don't 
want to use cannabis, don't. If you don't want your kids using cannabis, by 
all means, don't let them. But don't not only deny it, but make criminals 
of people who do wish to use it.

always be there -- were not monopolized by criminal gangs who put all kinds 
of garbage in the dope.

Simply not knowing the exact purity of the product alone leads to most 
overdoses.  *Very few people* have the discipline (and i know a couple) to 
hold down a job and make good enough money to support a daily habit -- 
while taking detox vacations now and then to keep tolerance at bay -- 
without anybody having any idea.

A true junkie acts/seems "normal" when he's had his/her fix.  But out of 
all the addicts out there, not many are functional and they are behind much 
of the home invasions and general thefts that occur in this nation.

We need more liberal drug laws, regulate legal heroin for addicts

down crime and HIV/Hep C rates.

Too bad the DEA is going nowhere, it is a very powerful bureaucracy.

drug (pure heroin like in UK hospitals) is far less liver-toxic than 
alcohol or acetaminophen (Tylenol).  It is soft on the body, but extremely 
addictive... also it is the street adulterants dealers cut the dope with -- 
toxic substances or other synthetic opiates like fentanyl/alpha-fentanyl.

The problem is, as true as that is... this mentality leads to addiction.  I 
had to go to rehab myself and i know the addiction grabs your soul, but 
physically heroin is not neurotoxic nor is it liver-toxic.  Tylenol and 
alcohol *literally are* worse for the liver than heroin.

the way crack or crystal meth does.  In short, if you have enough money to 
maintain your habit and have access clean dope... you can live as long as 
William Burroughs (until 82) being a junkie most of your life.

Overdose is by far the biggest risk but that is not because of the drug 
itself as much as the lack of regulations on purity. People don't know how 
much they are taking or how much their tolerance went down between 
binges... and then they die.

I am only answering in a matter-of-fact way.  Not endorsing heroin, but the 
truth is that morphine, hydrocodone, heroin... the only opiate that is 
neurotoxic is Demerol and that is being phased out.  They are ALL wildly 
addictive tho and i learned that the hard way... so don't go doing the damn 
thing.

But regardless, facts are facts. Heroin is not liver toxic... 
alcohol/Tylenol are.  Not a matter of opinion, no matter how dangerous 
heroin is on the street.

comments.text:
+lovetownsend She would have become schizophrenic even if she had not used 
cannabis.  Paranoid schizophrenia is an dysfunction in the brain's 
neurochemical function brought about by genetic abnormalities.  The THC in 
cannabis mimics a natural neurotransmitter found in the brain called 
anandimide.  Schizophrenia is associated with a significant decrease in 
dopamine reuptake in certain parts of the brain associated with sensory 
data interpretation.  They are not related at all, and all of the studies 
that attempted to link the two where thoroughly debunked.

I personally, meaning from personal experience, say marijuana is worse than

from weed (I have never experienced panic attacks without weed, except for 
a month after the first panic attack) and honestly I can say I've never 
experienced anxiety before my first panic attack. Now it's something I live 
with. I don't smoke weed anymore, but I think it's kind of ridiculous to 
say weed is harmless. I don't care if other people do it because it's not 
my business.

But people spin the marijuana issue like it's the "god drug" meaning it's 
the cure all drug. It's not. It has it's positive and negatives just like 
everything else. But everybody shines it like it's a miracle drug. In

the drug. Every pot smoker I have talked to has this problem. And don't

have cut back or even quit smoking).﻿

comments.text:
As probably the only person in this chat-thingy with some real shitty 
anxiety problems, (not to down play your anxiety Mr. Mathew Bell) I can 
confirm that Mary Jane can have some scary side effects for the unlucky 
like Mat and I and it's not 100% harmless. However... weed is not to blame, 
at least not all the blame. This isn't a black and white issue. Blaming 
weed for for your panic attacks isn't fair and it just translate to the 
brain that if you do X then you will have a panic attack. That's not 
helping anything, and it certainly isn't going to help your anxiety. It 
just provokes it. Makes it happen. And then you will be stuck in a loop.

 I too had the same thought process you shared Matt. For 2 years I 
absolutely refused to get anywhere near the stuff. Then guess what? I still 
had panic attacks and bad ones. One day I decided to play a racing game. It 
was a three man race with me in the lead with only one lap to go. Then I 
felt the sensation building up. The closer I got to the end the worse it 
became. By the time I was 3/4 the way there I couldn't feel my hands 
anymore and my legs were starting to go too. At that point I dashed to the 
console to turn it off. Then as I sat there for what seemed like hours 
getting my body back to normal, I wept. I was so fucking mad that once 
again my disorder got in the way of something I loved.

From that day on I vowed to not let fear of having a panic attack give me a 
panic attack. I could talk for years about different methods and what not 
to help prevent and stop them, but just know it didn't happen over night as 
it's a mental and physical problem. I'm not saying you should smoke weed or 
anything. All I'm saying is fight the motherfucker. With every ounce of 
your being. Meds or what not, doesn't matter. Don't let it get in the way 
of anything Period. 

Also, as to not sound too much like a douche for down-playing Matt. My bad 
panic attacks consist of me on the ground in full body paralysis(except 
with pain) where what feels like every muscles in my hands and legs are on 
fire. Think rigamortis or something. Everything lockups in such a painful 
fashion. Fun times.
comments.author: Gobbie Bag

comments.text:
+Matt Leonard I don't think it was tainted.  What he describes is a very 
real possible reaction to cannabis use, and one I have experienced myself. 
 After smoking a large amount of cannabis after I had abstained for a few 
months, I had a panic attack.  I became disoriented, cold and sweaty, 
cramped muscles, and anxiety.  This was a very bad reaction to marijuana, 
but is actually a reaction that can occur after smoking too many cigarettes 
when you are not tolerant to the nicotine.  Panic attacks are the body's 
natural response to a wide range of drastic and unforeseen changes to 
neurochemistry, but what everyone needs to remember is that they are 
temporary and harmless.  I am very well versed in mental health and 
neuroscience issues, so I knew what the symptoms of a panic attack were and 
even during the attack I was able to remain relatively calm and knew it 
would pass.  Panic attacks do not cause long term anxiety, and cannabis use 
cannot create an anxiety problem where before there was none.

I think the comparisons to alcohol come too often and they dodge the 
ultimate question of whether pot has any harmful effects.  To me, it's like 
saying that bleach is safe to drink draino is safe because it is less 
harmful than cyanide.  The statement does nothing to say what harm it could 
cause only that it causes LESS. 

As for the long term effects, we don't know for sure.  But we know at least

comments.author: HyrdaRancher

comments.text:
+HyrdaRancher I agree that the short term toxicity is not the biggest 
issue. And of course, if you smoke weed on a daily basis for years, there 
is a chance that youll have somewhat problems with mental health. But same 
goes for alcohol. 
However, the long term physical damages are very short to what alcohol or 
cigarettes do. 
Now when you talk the addiction-factor, people will jump out and say its 
totally non-addictive. Which might be particulary true for mentally stable 
humans, but i wouldnt hold on to that statement. Every substance has some 
addictive things to it, although there is absolutely no physical addiction 
with marijuana. 
And nobody has the money to smoke his own bodyweight, but you can smoke a 
ton of marijuana and still be okay.
comments.author: Masterlostfreaky

comments.text:
LD50 is not the only categorical determinant for how dangerous a drug is.  
I am not saying pot is as bad as alcohol or any other drug.  I am merely 
saying hat if one takes in THC over dozens of years regularly, we don't 
know if it has any identifiable correlations with health effects. 

Saying you can sit in a corner and smoke your weight in pot isn't a 
statement that it is safe any more than saying that humans can hit an LD50 
on water makes it unsafe.  Lethal dose is one of a number of factors.  If 
we acted like it was the determining factor, tobacco would be perfectly 
safe since it is not feasible to overdose on it without the use of patches. 

Additionally, toxicity can be generated by mixing chemicals.  Nothing wrong 
with smelling bleach, nothing wrong with smelling ammonia...but bleach and 
ammonia together...

Long story short, please stop peddling this crap about "it has no LD50" as 
if that made it safe.  It does nothing to move the movement forward and 
only shows that we don't understand what constitutes toxicity in humans.

comments.text:
First of all, my comment was meant to illustrate the absurdity of 
Bottocelli's statement that "as a public health person, what we look at is 
not the relative risk." Obviously, if a real public health person has one 
case of someone who ate too many brownies and another case of heroin 
overdose, they immediately know what the priority is.

Some people apparently don't like my use of the word "overdose" in 
conjunction with marijuana. You're being dense. People eat too many 
brownies, not realizing how much THC they're consuming, and panic or pass 
out in public and end up in the ER. It happens. Try sucking down the THC 
equivalent of a quarter ounce, you'll see what I'm talking about. I was not 
trying to suggest that THC overdose is  dangerous. I was saying it is NOT 
dangerous, and everyone in the ER would prioritize it as fast as Jimmy.
comments.author: vanteesomeone

comments.text:
+Trevor Patton 
﻿
+Zak Faircloth

That is not how an "overdose" is defined. Get your facts right. Panic and 
anxiety attacks can be caused even with low doses and it's got more to do 
with the individual user's brain and feelings than it is to do with weed 
(panic attacks are caused by the brain going into defensive and confused 
mode, not from weed causing some sort of irreversible damage - panic 
attacks leave no health risks AT ALL, it's just a "defensive" system built 
into the human body).

An overdose would mean reaching a drug's toxic/lethal dose, which is 
physically impossible with marijuana, even throught the use of some 
extraordinary or rare methods - it is impossible. It is impossible to 
breathe in enough smoke (can't even breathe in that much oxygen, if 
compared) within 15 minutes to reach the toxic dose of marijuana (you 
wouldn't even reach 1/100-1/1000 of the dose before dying of oxygen 
deprivation or passing out/falling asleep due to the same reason or weed's 
seducing power).

comments.text:
That's true, and I think people should be educated about the truth.  It's 
not without its problems, but we all recognize that its problems pale in 
comparison to other substances.  Relative to other substances that are 
taken recreationally, pot is benign.  You won't OD on pot, you won't become 
violent.  While some people use it to their detriment, we have plenty of 
examples of responsible adult use.  For every unemployed pothead I know, I 
know 5 responsible users.

We need to dispense with the Reefer Madness-esque propaganda about pot, and 
start teaching people the *actual* impact it has.  The drug war has failed 
- pot use has not declined in this country despite the harsh penalties that 
states impose.  If we want a healthier society, the government needs to 
realize that pot isn't going away, and start to deal with it rationally.

comments.text:
+AEgamesFtw
Yes, in fact, that is exactly what the drug schedules are supposed to be a 
measure of.  From the DEA website:

Drugs, substances, and certain chemicals used to make drugs are classified 
into five (5) distinct categories or schedules depending upon the drug’s 
acceptable medical use and the drug’s abuse or dependency potential. The 
abuse rate is a determinate factor in the scheduling of the drug; for 
example, Schedule I drugs are considered the most dangerous class of drugs 
with a high potential for abuse and potentially severe psychological and/or 
physical dependence. As the drug schedule changes-- Schedule II, Schedule 
III, etc., so does the abuse potential-- Schedule V drugs represents the 
least potential for abuse.
comments.author: modelmajorpita

comments.text:
+modelmajorpita The schedules don't classify which drugs are "worse" than

comments.author: Gbatemper E

comments.text:
+styx85
Actually, addictiveness and harmfulness is a major part of the 
classification system, as that determines whether a substance can only be 
used in a hospital, requires a prescription, or is over the counter.

From the DEA website:

"Drugs, substances, and certain chemicals used to make drugs are classified 
into five (5) distinct categories or schedules depending upon the drug’s 
acceptable medical use and the drug’s abuse or dependency potential. The 
abuse rate is a determinate factor in the scheduling of the drug; for 
example, Schedule I drugs are considered the most dangerous class of drugs 
with a high potential for abuse and potentially severe psychological and/or 
physical dependence."

"Schedule I drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no 
currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse. Schedule I 
drugs are the most dangerous drugs of all the drug schedules with 
potentially severe psychological or physical dependence."

The lack of medical uses obviously isn't true of marijuana, heroin, or even 
ecstasy and LSD, yet they are kept schedule 1 despite several lawsuits 
because of their "addictiveness."
comments.author: modelmajorpita

comments.text:
+modelmajorpita That's not the difference between schedule I and II drugs, 
they're not ranked based on harmfulness and addictiveness. The main 
difference between schedule I and II is that sched. I drugs don't have an 
accepted medical use in treatment in the United States.

comments.text:
Published on Feb 6, 2014
"An Oregon Democrat literally threw up his hands in frustration Tuesday 
after failing to get a direct answer to his question about marijuana's 
dangers from the deputy director of the White House Office of National Drug 
Control Policy. Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-OR) asked Michael Botticelli, the 
drug czar's chief deputy, to identify the number of marijuana overdoses 
reported in the previous five years. "To my knowledge, I don't know if 
there have been instances of specific overdose-related deaths," Botticelli 
said...".* Ben Mankiewicz (co-host of What The Flick?! and TYT Sports) and 
comedian Jimmy Dore break it down on The Young Turks.

*Read more here from Travis Gettys / The Raw Story:
http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2014/02/05/oregon-dem-destroys-top-drug-official-who-cant-say-if-weeds-less-addictive-than-meth/

comments.text:
Wow, we had an assembly today in high school (I'm Canadian) and the 
presentation was all normal and what not

And then the principle said "And the biggest lie they have been telling you 
is that Marijuana is alright on your body and even good for you" And he 
switched slides to show Marijuana and some mini documentary on it.

Esentially the documentary said that young people are "2X more likely to 
develop Schizophrenia from hard core use" And then they showed a few 
examples.

2 Problems.

1) They NEVER said what it doubled from? was it 2%? 0.5% It was soooo 
clearly a propaganda of fear mongering that they refused to look at any 
other side of the drug besides the "horrible evil part"

2) The documentary looked 20 years old and had no verifiable sources I 
could see throughout the clip.

People became so pissed that the principle had to stop the video and then 
after a couple questions that got the whole crowd clapping he said "Ok we 
will answer questions AFTER the assembly" We all knew he wanted people to 
give up and leave at the end.

At the end a quarter of the people stayed and we pointed out how 
hypocritical he was to allow grade 11 students to use the smoke pit, but 
threaten to prosecute all Marijuana smokers.

My final point. In my law textbook I remember reading something along these 
lines

Basically Heroin and Ecstasy got classified 3 tiers (out of 4) lower (less 
dangerous) then Marijuana (tier4) that held the heaviest punishments and 
was considered much more dangerous.

Honestly I am really happy if anyone reads this far, I just was shocked at 
the hypocrisy and lies I had to sit through today.﻿

comments.text:
It's a fine question.  He literally pointed out that he was against 
marijuana, but he was calling out the director for his unwillingness to 
answer a direct question.  If it was in judicial court he would be brought 
up on contempt.

Now if he asked that question and intended to base policy entirely upon 
that one answer, that would be another story.  That wasn't the case 
though.  It was a comprehensive hearing (one of many), with a lot of other 
questions as well.

The problem is, the director and those like him try and paint marijuana as 
a drug as harmful as the others mentioned which all studies have shown is 
untrue, and he states that quite clearly as well.  THAT fact is harmful to 
the well-being of people since, as he pointed out, pretty much anyone who 
actually uses marijuana (and those who study it) know how little harm it 
truly does.  So telling people its just as harmful as harder drugs, lessens 
the perceived danger of the harder drugs because of the mentality drilled 
into the public that 'if its the same as those, then they must not be any 
worse than what I already have done.'  When the reality is, those drugs are 
much much worse.

tl:dr: Yes the question is valid.

comments.text:
Can't comment on the stats in the US as I don't know them (and couldn't be 
bothered looking them up.) In Australia the costs to our health system due 
to alcahol and tabacco abuse are the two highest percentages for drug 
related illness on our current lists. All other drugs here account for only 
15% of the cost of our health budget due to drug abuse.

Having said that, crystal meth is the drug causing most of the social 
problems here and it is endemic in some areas like where I live. High 
unemployment, racism, few opportunities. It's taken over from heroin and 
"speed" meth. One in three adults in my suburb, one of the worser ones, 
would be users. Petty crime, assaults, etc; all due to the psychosis' 
caused by this drug or the need to feed a habit, the child neglect, etc; 
are becoming more common. I'm told places in the US are no different in 
this regards.

We don't get pot heads roaming the streets looking for victims here. No pot 
heads doing house invasions. Bugger all pot heads thieving to support a 
habit. Nobody is being knifed over a gram (or several) of cannabis. 
Habitual thieves that smoke pot may commit crimes, but not even close to 
every, let alone most users in town. That's all being done by "Ice Heads" 
and to a lesser extent heroin addicts.

The thing about crystal meth is, according to SBS's Dateline a few years 
back (they broke the Abu Graib story),  there's only three factories in the 
world, all of them in India that manufacture one of the key ingrediants 
reqired to bake crystal meth (Ice.). All that has to happen to close the 
whole "Ice" trade is to close down those three factories, or update their 
facilities to produce newer chemicals, and the whole trades gone.

Admitedly someone will come up with a newer chemical drug formulae for 
dangerous recreational use at some point, but the "Ice" problem would be 
gone. Then down to rehabilitation and recovery programmes to clean up the 
absolute social mess it's left many areas of many countries in.

Pot.... bi-polarity, some forms of clinical depression, smoking it very 
young, yes, they all cause problems in some pot users, mostly treatable. 
Compared to the real costs socially, physically, economically, related 
deaths, assaults, robberies, fatal accidents, incarcerations, etc; from 
harder drugs going "hard on pot" seems to lack critical prioritization. A 
criminal triage process. It's probably wasting police resources that could 
best be used with greater effect else where on more pressing law 
enforcement issues.

Bleeding obvious which is more dangerous. Is this Chief Deputy bloke a real 
copper? Well said Mr Blumenaur.﻿
